node.title: Smoothed-Finite Element
node.bodyText:
Hi dear MOOSE experts and users,
I am simulating a large scale geomechanical model including fault. In order to avoid sharp change of the material properties near the fault, I decided to apply phase-field approach for properly modeling. But, as you probably guess, by doing so  much time is needed for convergence. Then, I just found Smoothed Finite Element, which is more or less different in creating shape function in respect to standard FEM implemented in MOOSE, but it has higher convergence rate.
Now, I wondering to know, is there any way to control the shape functions. Since, based on the formulation of the Smoothed FEM, after obtaining the displacement using standard FEM, smoothing process is being performed on elements resulting a smooth matrix. So, I want to know whether it is possible to perform smoothing process in MOOSE.
Thank you in advance

Hello
The shape functions are provided by our underlying finite element library, libmesh. So I'd encourage you to ask this on their github.
https://github.com/libMesh/libmesh/discussions
Are you looking to develop this feature?
Guillaume

node.title: Checkpoint system does not work with an explicit solver
node.bodyText:
Trying to use --recover with an explicit calculation leads to the following error
[2]PETSC ERROR: --------------------- Error Message --------------------------------------------------------------
[2]PETSC ERROR: Object is in the wrong state
[2]PETSC ERROR: Matrix is missing diagonal entry 0
[2]PETSC ERROR: See https://petsc.org/release/faq/ for trouble shooting.
[2]PETSC ERROR: Petsc Release Version 3.16.5, unknown

I have been using the checkpoint system without issue for the same simulation but with an implicit time integrator.
Here is my executioner block
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  end_time = 9e-5
  dt = 8e-10
  solve_type = LINEAR
  dtmin = 1e-20

  [TimeIntegrator]
    type = CentralDifference
    use_constant_mass = true
  []
[]

I can give more information as needed, but before that I want to check if this is an inherent limitation that I am unaware of.
Thank you in advance

Hello
recover and central difference time integration should work, it's tested by the test suite.
use_constant_mass = true might not be supported though
might also be the solve_type = LINEAR that is an issue.
Could you please try to comment these out and report on your findings? (they are optimizations, the code should run without)
Guillaume

Thank you for your answer!
It seems that the issue was with use_constant_mass = true
Without that option enabled I able to use the checkpoint system
great thanks for reporting this. I ll submit an issue and we ll fix this at some point.

node.title: Preconditioner reuse -- speeding up Newton/LU runs by 10x
node.bodyText:
For better or worse some of us run apps using a full Newton solve and superlu_dist to solve the linear equations.  Typically in my group here at ANL we run "medium sized" jobs like this all the time on workstations.  They might take a few hours to a few days and typically involve up to a couple million dofs.  Anything larger and we move to HPC and use an iterative linear solver preconditioned by hypre.  But running jobs with superlu is much faster, assuming you have enough memory to factor the linearized system of equations.
We do a lot of these medium sized problems.  Here's an example -- some RVE type model of a microstructure with a bunch of inclusions providing some strength and we're pulling on it to simulate a flow curve.  I can provide the input file and mesh for those who are curious, but it uses one of the things we have in deer that's not in tensor_mechanics.

If I run this example problem on 24 ranks (~25000 dofs/rank) with the following solver block it takes about 116 minutes to run 10 time steps.
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package -ksp_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu superlu_dist preonly'

If I run with this solver block, which involves some new options I added over here and needs a hacked version of libmesh, the exact same problem takes 11 minutes.  So it's 10ish times faster.
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package -ksp_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu superlu_dist gmres'
  l_tol = 1e-8

  reuse_preconditioner = true
  reuse_l_max_its = 50

What the new options do is allow NonlinearProblem and the associated libmesh PetscNonlinearSolver to reuse the LU factored Jacobian from previous nonlinear iterations and even previous timesteps as the preconditioner for GMRES to continue to solve the current linearized system of equations.  The heuristic is you just keep reusing your LU decomposition until the number of GMRES iterations exceeds some number -- here 50.  At that point you just refactor the system, do your GMRES (which is just iterative refinement during this first nonlinear iteration), and then keep using that new LU decomposition as a preconditioner for awhile.
This is definitely a heuristic but in my experience it works very, very well because really the structure of the nonlinear equations isn't changing all that much between iterations and changes only very slowly across timesteps.  In this problem with reuse we only factor the linear system only 1 time, versus 30 times for the "base" set.  And I'm not the only one to have noticed how well this works: the Intel PARDISO folks have been using it for 8 years or so and it's supported in PETSc via SNESSetLagPreconditionerPersists and SNESSetLagPreconditioner, which are of course how I implemented it in the branch.
Reconfiguring things to allow preconditioner reuse within a single time step is easy.  Allowing use across multiple time steps requires a change to libmesh because right now it clears the SNES instance in between each time step.  I started a discussion over in libmesh on changing this behavior, my preliminary tests suggest it's not that hard and doesn't seem to cause any memory issues.
So all that said:

Would anyone else find this useful?
Does anyone more informed than me foresee problems in not releasing the SNES instance between time steps?  If we go ahead I'll make the old "release after every nonlinear solve" behavior the default, but it would be good to know if MOOSE (or libmesh) somehow relies on this behavior to ensure cross-compatibility with arbitrary apps wanting to use this heuristic.

I'm interested. We use Newton/LU for Navier Stokes too currently (we will have a segregated solver soon though). But the problem is pretty non-linear so no guarantees reusing preconditioners would work.

This would be very useful. Also, defaults could be set on a per-app basis, so that shouldn't create any compatibility issue moving forward -- we could keep the current moose behavior as the default and let apps opt in using this new capability by chaging their default.

For those who are interested you can play with this branch.  Note that it points to a fork of libmesh here.  There is a PR open on libmesh to get my changes in over there, then I can make a proper PR on MOOSE.
The solver parameters to play with are
  reuse_preconditioner = true
  reuse_preconditioner_max_its = 30

and you'll want to use that with something like
  petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_type -pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
  petsc_options_value = 'gmres lu superlu_dist'
I should add I'm curious how it will work for other physics outside of tensor_mechanics.

Agreed that this is useful, and a 10x speedup definitely warrants develping this! Our group also runs in this mode (moderate sized problems with superlu) quite a bit, and I've often wondered how much time we could save by reusing the preconditioner. It seems like this might be even more helpful if you're using PJFNK rather than Newton because in that case, you can often get more mileage with a less-than-perfect preconditioner than you would with Newton.
I guess it depends on the problem, but I can see the benefit of allowing to reuse the preconditioner between steps. I can't think of anything offhand that would be an issue there, other than the fact that the problem might change and the preconditioner might not be that great. In particular, we often use damage models in which we lag the damage by one step, and I imagine the performance would be hampered considerably by that. I'd just add separate options that control whether to reuse the preconditioner between steps or within the current step only.

@reverendbedford thanks for sharing!
I find it slower compared to hypre for my problem:
Porousflow, highly heterogenous, have many faults (discontinuity), a massive model (6 million elements), complex surface drainage setup.
hypre would take 15 mins for 1 steady-step to converge on my workstation, but reuse_preconditioner wouldn't converge after 30 mins:

here is my setup for hypre:
[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre    boomeramg'

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-15
  l_tol = 1e-06
  l_max_its = 150
  nl_max_its = 50
[]

maybe I didn't setup reuse_preconditioner correctly
Kind regards,
Traiwit

You need to run a transient problem to see if it helps or not (or have a steady problem with a huge number of nonlinear iterations).  It reuses the preconditioner across times steps, which is why I was able to get such good speedup.

I see, noted, I will give it a go with pit backfill + reflooding problem, and get back to you soon
thank you @reverendbedford

Also: I don't know your problems but
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-15

seems a bit much.  It might have trouble solving the linearized systems in a reasonable amount of iterations when you're trying to converge things down that fine.  But maybe it would be okay as long as you are comparing everything at the same tolerances?
Could you try something like:
  petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_type -pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
  petsc_options_value = 'gmres lu superlu_dist'

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  l_tol = 1e-5
  l_max_its = 50
  nl_max_its = 50

  reuse_preconditioner = true
  reuse_preconditioner_max_its = 30

and see if that works for you?
By the way, there's nothing to stop you from using this with hypre.  In your example above you could also just do
[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre    boomeramg'

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-15
  l_tol = 1e-06
  l_max_its = 150
  nl_max_its = 50

  reuse_preconditioner = true
  reuse_preconditioner_max_its = 100
[]

and see what happens.

node.title: “Open” Boundary Condition for Species Fluxes?
node.bodyText:
My goal is to have a defined flux of species and associated energy coming into a chamber, reacting inside, and then leaving freely through an outlet on the other end. Setting a FunctionNeumann on the inlet and proper BCs where there is a solid surface is easy enough, but the "open" boundary at the outlet appears to be much trickier.
The system I'm simulating primarily uses the application Zapdos/Crane, but I was wondering if there exists a BC in the basic MOOSE framework or in one of its modules that computes the values of a given variable on the boundary to be the same values in the elements/points adjacent to it, or perhaps something similar to this to effectively "open" the boundary?
Edit: I came across "PorousFlowOutflowBC" which seems to do exactly what I want from the description of it, but I've never used this module before and I'm unsure of what I would need to add to my simulation to make it work, if anything. "ChemicalOutFlowBC" also seems like an option, but I'm confused about the porosity term.
Thank you!

Hello
Is this a flow simulation? If so then you could set a pressure boundary condition for an outlet.
Is there an advective component and/or a diffusive component?
Guillaume

Well, it's a weird mix because I'm simulating the plasma using Zapdos/Crane on top of a background flow from INS. I ran a simple INS input file with a defined velocity at the inlet, no slip everywhere else, and left the outlet undefined and it produced a velocity field as expected. I used this INS exodus file as the mesh for my plasma simulation, and I have a kernel that couples my plasma species to the flow field for a "convection" (not sure if thats the correct term; just going off what the kernel is called). My thought process for this is that the background gas is much higher in density than the plasma species, so any plasma interactions have very little effect on the flow field. The plasma species indeed experience diffusion and advection from the electric fields. (I'm unsure if this advection is the same as what you're thinking; It seems advection & convection are often used interchangeably and mean different things in different contexts.)
I hope this helped clarify!

So a BC with values at the boundary being the same as values on the element would be 0 normal face gradient or no flux.
In flow this is typically a fully developed conditions, where while there is a pressure gradient, the velocity profile does not change when those are reached. In the INS-FE part of the NS module, I think this is https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/bcs/INSMomentumNoBCBCLaplaceForm.html
or a Dirichlet boundary condition on pressure.
@lindsayad knows more about that part of the NS module

If your advection term is not integrated by parts, then a natural boundary condition (no bc specification at all) will often work well. However, this does implicitly impose a zero-gradient condition as @GiudGiud stated since you are implicitly saying that your diffusive flux is zero. If you want no conditions on the boundary, then you have to code up BCs of the variety that @GiudGiud linked-to. Essentially you will want to write in code-form the surface terms that result when you integrate your weak form by parts. If you are working with Zapdos, I see there are a lot of *DoNothingBC classes that I wrote a very long time ago. I can't guarantee that they still work (they are probably mostly untested) but the concepts in there should be good

node.title: Irreversibility issue in phase field fracture
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE experts
I am using the rate-dependent phase-field fracture equation for some thermo-mechanical problems. I found that the value of the phase-field parameter decreases in certain locations. Can you please suggest any possible reasons for such phenomena?
Best
Avtar
It's not clear to me from your description whether you are using moose modules or your app. Can you elaborate?
I am using MOOSE module for solving the phase-field fracture.
Great, then sharing a MWE that reproduces this issue is the easiest way we can help.
@asingh-mit any update on this?
Yes, It is solved. I used the bounds on the variable. It bounds are not used, irreversibility issue arises.

node.title: "Functionality is not available" error when using checkpoint
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE team
I recently tried to install moose on our HPC referring to the procedure from the installation pages. However, once I finished the compilation of libmesh and do some tests with "checkpoint=true" set, it returned the following error message
ERROR: Functionality is not available.
Make sure LIBMESH_HAVE_XDR is defined at build time
The XDR interface is not available in this installation
I simply ran the following commends while compiling the libmesh
scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh --with-dof-id-bytes=8 --enable-vtk --with-vtk-include=$VTKINCLUDE_DIR --with-vtk-lib=$VTKLIB_DIR
it seems that I should add some options to enable the XRD, which had never been set in the former procedure.
Could anyone inform me of the solution to this issue?
Thank you in advance
Did anyone encounter the same error message as me?
I imaging that there is some missing package on your machine that is causing libMesh to disable XDR support. If you look at text in during the configure, can you find the sections that mention XDR?

Thank you very much for your reply. I saved the log of compiling the libMesh, and it indeed mentioned that "XDR is not supported."
/////
checking for built-in XDR support... no
checking for XDR support in /usr/include/tirpc... no
////
I compiled this on our newest machine with 96 avx512 cores and essences:  gcc/8.3.1, openmpi/4.0.4, cmake/3.18.4,
which is wield since I changed to another machine with different compiling essences (24 avx2 cores w/ gcc/8.3.0, openmpi/4.0.2, cmake/3.18.4), and at that time, I could successfully compile the libmesh with XDR.
Is this issue occurred solely due to the differences of compelling packages, or is it also related to the usage of avx512 cores?
Thank you again, and look forward to your prompt reply.
@milljm Do you know what could be missing that is causing XDR to be disabled?
See this answer for future reference #20479 (reply in thread)

Hello
Libmesh needs to be configured with netcdf4 to load this file.
Did you re-create the mesh file between the two versions? If you did, make sure to see #19264 before re-exporting it.
Guillaume
No,I have't re-creat it. the mesh file between the two version is same.
did you use conda for libmesh or did you install from the scripts in moose/scripts/?
I used conda, just like the MOOSE website.
@milljm conda build has libmesh compiled without HDF5 / netcfd4 right?
@roystgnr for the sake of closing this, how do we enable netcdf4 in libmesh again? I remember searching at the time and could not find it

NetCDF4 is automatically enabled whenever HDF5 is enabled, but HDF5 is never enabled automatically in libMesh (it's one of those things that often is preinstalled in /usr/lib/ but we never want to auto-include that whole directory lest we get whatever atavistic package versions are there).
If you already have HDF5, setting $HDF5_DIR is the best way to get us to check $HDF5_DIR/libs and $HDF5_DIR/include for libraries and headers.  If you have an install but it doesn't have that subdirectory structure, making a couple symbolic links in your own new $HDF5_DIR is currently the best way to handle it.
If you don't already have HDF5, you ought to be able to get it now just by using Moose's update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh, which will ask PETSc to build HDF5 if it doesn't find it elsewhere, after which point libMesh will autodetect PETSc's HDF5 installation.

node.title: In computing the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a symmetric rank-2 tensor, the PETSC LAPACK syev routine returned error code 2
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose users,
I am running a simulation using tensor mechanics and am seeing this error repeatedly. I tried to reduce the time step but it didn't help. I searched and found one relevant discussion  #16288.  My preconditioning and executioner blocks are as follows:
[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]

  [./TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 0.01
    growth_factor = 1.0000001
    cutback_factor = 0.9
    optimal_iterations = 15
    iteration_window = 2
    reject_large_step = true
    reject_large_step_threshold = 0.1
  [../]


  type = Transient
  nl_max_its = 15
  scheme = bdf2
  solve_type = PJFNK
  petsc_options_iname = -pc_type
  petsc_options_value = asm
  l_max_its = 40
  l_tol = 1.0e-3
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-5
  start_time = 0.0
  num_steps = 1000
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
[]

I am running my executable in parallel using mpi as mpiexec -n 4 ../../../.././drx__ti64-opt -i beta_transformed_Ti64_case1.i. I will be grateful for any guidance or references regarding this issue.
Warm Regards,
Ritam Chatterjee

Hello
Did you try to change a few parameters and see if the error goes away?
Like running it in serial, using lu for preconditioning etc
Guillaume

We use LAPACK subroutine at several places in TensorMechanics kernels/materials. It has nothing to do with the Solver option. Very likely, your problem has unrealistic deformation that causes eigendecomposition fail. Could you track where does the error come from?

Hi Guillaume, yes I am trying automatic_scaling = true,petsc_options_iname = -snes_ksp_ew according to this webpage https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/executioners/Steady.html. I will try lu with serial execution and other options and let you know.
Hi Wen, thank you for the response. Such failure is occurring during elastic deformation. I checked dislocation density, strain tensor components and Cauchy stress but the values seem alright. I will check other tensors such as Fp,Fe and let you know. I am simulating uniaxial compression for Ti6Al4V with beta phase at alpha grain boundaries. Is there anything else I can do to track this error?
I forgot what the name of that parameter is, but were you using EigenSolution or TaylorExpansion? Try switching to TaylorExpansion and see if that error persists.

I found it:
# decomposition_method = EigenSolution
decomposition_method = TaylorExpansion

Hi Gary, thank you for your reply. I am using ComputeFiniteStrain, which considers TaylorExpansion as default. However, from your and Wen's suggestion, I got the idea of adding use_displaced_mesh = true to all auxkernels and user objects in my input file as I had been facing convergence issues with the progress of plastic deformation. This seems to have helped definitely. Additionally, based on Guillaume's advice, I tried running in serial with lu and noticed good improvement in speed. Subsequently, I have run in parallel after making changes to the executioner block as follows:
[Executioner]

  [./TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 0.001
    growth_factor = 1.0000001
    cutback_factor = 0.9
    optimal_iterations = 15
    iteration_window = 2
    reject_large_step = true
    reject_large_step_threshold = 0.1
  [../]


  type = Transient
  nl_max_its = 15
  scheme = bdf2
  solve_type = PJFNK
  petsc_options = -snes_ksp_ew
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -sub_pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'asm ilu'
  l_max_its = 40
  l_tol = 1.0e-3
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-5
  start_time = 0.0
  num_steps = 20000
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
  automatic_scaling = true
  scaling_group_variables = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]


Overall, the simulation is much faster now. However, I've again run into the same PETSC LAPACK error but after significantly more number of time steps. I will explore other options and check.
Thanks and regards,
Ritam
You could also try the ElementJacobianDamper which prevents over distortion of elements. I've had good experience using this damper.

Hi Gary, I will try ElementJacobianDamper and let you know. As a test, I added decomposition_method = EigenSolution to the tensor mechanics Master action block in my input file. Now, I haven't seen the error after almost ~15000 time steps with initial dt = 0.005. However, dt has now decreased to 1.5e-5. Is such a decrease expected in multiphase polycrystal plasticity problems?

Hi Guillaume,
I was able to figure out the problem. The time step was decreasing due to improper node set generation using BoundingBoxNodeSetGenerator as explained in this thread #20581. I did try ElementJacobianDamper but faced convergence issues, which I can't clearly remember now. I'll check again. I modified my Executioner block and now the simulation is significantly faster (4 times) than earlier when I run using MPI on 8 cores. The executioner block is below:
[Executioner]

  [./TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 0.05
    growth_factor = 1.0000001
    cutback_factor = 0.9
    optimal_iterations = 15
    iteration_window = 2
    reject_large_step = true
    reject_large_step_threshold = 0.1
  [../]


  type = Transient
  nl_max_its = 15
  scheme = bdf2
  solve_type = PJFNK
  petsc_options = '-snes_ksp_ew'
  petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_gmres_restart -pc_type -pc_hypre_type -pc_hypre_boomeramg_max_iter'
  petsc_options_value = '201                hypre    boomeramg      4'
  l_max_its = 40
  l_tol = 1.0e-3
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-5
  start_time = 0.0
  num_steps = 20000
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
  line_search = none
  snesmf_reuse_base = false
  automatic_scaling = true
  scaling_group_variables = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  [./Predictor]
    type = SimplePredictor
    scale = 1.0
    skip_after_failed_timestep = true
  [../]
[]

Warm regards,
Ritam

node.title: Inquiry about outputting the values of concentration of all the points in 2D CH model
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
Do you know how I can output all the points' concentration in a 2D CH model in each time step?
I know there is one command, called LineValueSampler.
However, from its introduction, it can only output 1D model's concentration, right? Because it can only output one line's variable's value, right? Can it output 2D model's concentration? Or, is there other command that can output all the points' concentration in 2D mode?
Does everyone have any good suggestion?
Thank you very much.
Best regards,

Hello
You can use this VectorPostprocessor (outputs to CSV) for all element values:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/ElementValueSampler.html
or if you have a 2D array of points you can fit as a long parameter:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/PointValueSampler.html
Guillaume

Hi, Guillaume,
Thank you very much for your quick response.
Do you mean that I need to write the command as shown below?
[VectorPostprocessors]
[./element_value_sampler]
type = ElementValueSampler
variable = 'c'
sort_by = id
[../]
[]
How should I set the 'sort by' option? The 'sort by' option is set as id? And then I can get all the points' concentration? Will the csv file give me only one line and contains all of the points' concentration or it will be distributed by x axis and y axis?
And for your second suggestions, it seems that pointvaluesampler can only output several specific point's value, not the whole 2D matrix...

For the second suggestion, you could input a 2D matrix of points, it ll just not be very pretty, a very long parameter essentially.
I think the first suggestion should do what you want, if the Elements actually form the 2D matrix of points that you want

Better answer to this is to define a nodeset then use the NodalValueSampler
or a new subdomain then the ElementValueSampler
